Situation1: There is a scheduled family gathering on the calendar.
Expectation2: Repair or replace damaged wooden structures or components
Situation2: A house has structural wood damage from termites, and the carpenter needs to provide an urgent repair plan
Story: I glanced at the calendar, the date circled in red: family gathering at my daughter’s house. My grandson had called me last night, his voice bubbling with excitement about showing me his new train set. I promised him I’d be there, and I could already picture his face lighting up when I walked through the door. But this morning, my phone buzzed with a different kind of urgency—a client’s frantic message about termite damage spreading through their living room beams. The house was old, the wood brittle, and the family inside depended on me to keep their home safe. They needed an immediate assessment, maybe even repairs today, before the damage got worse. I felt the weight of both worlds pressing on my chest: the expectation to be the reliable grandfather, present and loving, and the duty to be the dependable carpenter, skilled and responsive. My hands, rough from years of work, trembled slightly as I tried to figure out how to be in two places at once, knowing that no matter what I chose, someone would be disappointed.
